Name: Republic & Empire
Description:
Subtitled: Rules for Miniatures Wargames of the 19th Century.

Appears to be self published, and is noted as a revision of the 1994 Cold Wars version.

The Introduction states: "These rules are intended to be used for any land conflict from the Napoleonic Wars through the Second Anglo-Boer War. Encompassing both colonial actions and conflicts between technologically advanced powers, they are intended for those who wish to recreate the lesser-known conflicts of the period, for which specifically tailored rules sets are often not available. They are designed as a framework that is easily modified to fit the specific situation being recreated. Alternately, these rules are good for those who wish to play battalion-level games that move quickly...Toward this end, any consistent basing system can be used, with the number of figures on a base left to the individual."

System focuses on fatigue instead of casualties as has measurements intended for 15mm games.

Name: Grand Prix Cribbage
Description: In Grand Prix Cribbage, players race each other around a twisting, turning, two-lane track using traditional Cribbage scoring methods.  Through strategic card play and and tactical pegging, each player attempts to avoid Collisions, Oil Spills and Spin Outs while trying to force his opponent into them.  By crossing over the inside lane before each turn in the track, a player can shorten the overall distance from 121 holes -- as in traditional Cribbage -- to 107 holes.  By taking advantage of the powerful "Slipstream", a trailing player can change the face of a game in a single hand.

Name: East High Forever Game
Description:
Game based on the Disney's High School Musical 3, the Senior Year.

From the box:
"Join the East High Gang as they step up to their greatest challenge - the future!  Senior year is full of fun when you meet Troy in the Gym to prepare for college tryouts, or share notes for final exams with Gabriella.  Will Mrs. Darbus cast you in this year's musical, or will you dance with your crush on prom night?  It's your choice and your future - so give the best performance you can!  Go Wildcats!"

Game includes : 
-6 pawns (based on characters from the show)
-6 different colored stands for the pawns
-6 decks of character cards (30 cards each)
-1 Event Card Deck (32 cards)
-156 graduation cap tokens
-1 gameboard representing the high school

Name: Football Game in a Tin
Description: This is a 2-4 player game.  The components include a folding game board, four different colored pawns, two dice, rules, and pocket sized tin.  Players roll dice to make yardage on the field and push their luck to get to the next down, and ultimately try to make a goal.

Name: Baseball Game in a Tin
Description: This is a dice game for 2 players.  The theme is baseball and players attempt to roll certain combinations on dice to get singles, doubles, homeruns, etc.  Game includes folding gameboard, dice, rules, and all packaged in an attractive tin.

Name: Fish Frenzy Toss
Description: This game is for 2-4 players.  Components include folding game board, and many different colorful fishes.  The game board represents a body of water with a sleeping fisherman floating in his boat and several scoring zones worth differing amounts.  The object is to toss or flick your fish to hit the highest scoring zones (or knock opponents fish off of them!) while avoiding the fisherman.

Name: Hand Puppets
Description:
Rhymes about the hare, the bear & sheep foster language skills

The game collection of the series "My very first games" offers
children different activities: the cute hand puppets and little rhymes will improve theirs linguistic and social skills. Playing and manipulating things with hands and fingers is excellent training for motor skills; a die and a memory game introduce children to games with rules.

Contents:
3 hand puppets
4 wooden flowers
4 wooden hearts
1 die with symbols

Name: Dream World A Fantasy Game
Description: This is a game for 2 to 4 players.  The game includes 4 cardboard pawns representing cartoony little girls, a foldable gameboard, cards, and item tokens.  The object of the game is to move your pawn around the board and collect the items (things little girls would want), by following card instructions.

Name: Robot Race
Description: Robot Race is a race for 2 to 4 players.  Game includes four different robot stand-up pawns in different colors, a fold out game map, and a spinner to determine each racers movement and other game effects.  Game is aimed at young kids.

Name: Joias
Description: Joias is a small card game for 3 to 6 players. Its objective is to get rid off all cards in your hand. The first player in each round plays a single, a pair, a trio, a quartet or a quintet (with a Joker), and other players must play the same type of combination, but with lower numbers. When nobody is capable of playing a new combination on that round, a new one start.

Name: Quatro
Description:
Quatro is a small card game for 3 to 5 players. The deck is numbered from 1 to 13 in four different suits. Each suit is on a different language (Portuguese, Spanish, French and English) so that the players can learn the numbers in all these languages.

The objective of the game is to form more collections than the other players of the four suits of the same number. You start with 5 cards on your hand and each round you ask another player for a number. That player must then give all his cards of that number to you. Your turn continues until you ask someone for a card he does not have.

The game continues until all quartets are formed.

Name: Grande Bataille, Grande Victoire
Description:
Subtitle: European Land Warfare from 1853-1871

From the Introduction: "This rules set has been written for the wargamers who enjoy a good "afternoon match," and not for those who like to get "bogged down" in rules minutiae. This is not to say that the historical integrity of this era in warfare has been compromised, It has not."

The rules are designed for 15mm miniatures, but has general conversion notes for 5mm and 25mm. Turns equal 15 minutes of real time, with castings representing approx. 60 individual troops. Units are rated with Quality Points (QP) and have a typical number of castings (marked as lost as combat occurs). It has a basic "orders" system and units fatigue if given too many attack orders in a row. Unit types have a set number of performable functions in a turn for movement, formation changes and other actions.

The rulebook itself is 32 pages, including eight pages of general troop listings for the major conflicts of the period. There is also a four page discussion of unit organizations and tactics for the armies listed.

Name: South Carolina 1788
Description:
South Carolina 1788: The South Carolina History Game.

This educational trivia game is played on a long track shaped like the border of the U.S. state of South Carolina. The question and answer cards contain 500 different questions about the history of the state. Up to four may play. Produced shortly before the state's bicentennial.

Components include: game board, cards, four pawns, and instructions.

Name: Bulls and Bears
Description: Bulls and Bears is to stocks what Monopoly is to real estate, or so says the box.  This game has the classic square Monopoly-like board with spinners in the center of the board that create the movement in stock prices.  The game also includes an audio cassette with a rules explanation.

Name: Desert Sword: Arabian Nightmare
Description:
First an add-on for Arabian Nightmare: The Kuwait War. 
Adding a map of Western Iraq and additional counters, plus rules for expanded games as originally published, plus an Operation Desert Sword scenario (since re-named "Operation Desert Sabre").

Game Scale:
Turn: 1-3 days for Military Action Segments (combat units), 3-6 days for Political Action Segments
Hex: 30 km
Unit: Battalion to Corps, Naval Squadrons, Air Wings

Game Inventory:
Two 22" X 34" mapsheet
Four countersheets (600 1/2" counters)
One 36 page Military Game Rules booklet
One 12 page Political Game Rules booklet
One 8 page introductory Game Rules booklet
One 12 page Summary Sheet Rules booklet
One 12 page Desert Sword Expansion Rules Booklet
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Decline and Fall: Byzantium at War – Field of Glory Gaming Companion
Description:
The seventh army supplement for the Field of Glory: Ancient and Medieval Wargaming Rules miniatures wargame. This supplement covers the Byzantine Empire, its allies and enemies from 493AD through the mid-11th Century. There are twenty-five separate lists, each with a sample starter army and point cost chart for making your own force.

The book itself is 80 pages printed in full color with photos of miniatures and paintings from various other Osprey books used throughout.

Armies included:
- Early Byzantine
- Later Moorish
- Later Visigothic
- African Vandal
- Italian Ostrogothic
- Early South Slav
- Lombard
- Maurikian Byzantine
- Christian Nubian
- Avar
- Western Turkish
- Arab Conquest
- Early Bulgar
- Thematic Byzantine
- Umayyad Arab
- Abbasid Arab
- Early North African Dynasties
- Khurasanian Dynasties
- Bedouin Dynasties
- Dailami Dynasties
- Kurdish Allies
- Bagratid Armenian Allies
- Pecheneg
- Ghaznavid
- Nikephorian Byzantine

Name: Hansel and Gretel
Description:
This game is for children Ages 4 - 8.

The game feature films based on well-known fairy tales children trying to escape from the house of witch Baba Jaga and she tries to catch them gingery house is full of mysterious lanes. Flying brooms and magic bullets of witch Baba Jaga ensure an exciting game.

Game is published in Polish and Lithuanian languages.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Hansel and Gretel

Name: Mathfacts Game
Description:
This is an older Milton Bradley title, cover art and MB logo appear to be from the 1970's.  It's designed to help kids learn math through board gaming.

The box cover claims to be "Self Checking, Self Instructional"

Game includes game board and four pyramidal pawns.

Name: Battles with Model Tanks
Description:
From Back Cover
The scope of wargaming is almost boundless.  Wargamers can create simulations of the simplest encounter or the grandest strategy.  Armoured warfare in miniature has a special appeal.
The model tank wargamer can take advantage of the superb range of miniature model tanks available and the many books detailing modern weaponry to recreate this style of fighting that was born on the Somme in 1916 and came of age in 1940.  Perfect scale models and accurate rules combine to produce an almost faultless simulation of tank warfare - all that is missing is the clatter of tracks, the roar of engines and the crump of shellfire.
This book lays the complete groundwork on the subject.  It explains how to use the many different armoured fighting vehicles, their guns, caliber, missile weight, range, angle of impact, thickness of armour; and does the same for anti-tank weapons.  It provides essential information on communications, mines, infantry co-operation, aircraft and armoured operations, and battlefields; it also provides practical information on how to assemble armoured forces in miniature and table-top terrains over which they can battle.
The authors are well known veteran wargamers.  Donald Featherstone served with the Royal Tank Regiment in North Africa and Italy during World War II; his associate, Keith Robinson, is an adviser to one of the main manufacturers of model fighting vehicles for wargamers.
Together they have clearly and simply brought this modern style of warfare to the table-top battlefield and provide technical and tactical advice against a fascinating background of wargaming narrative with ten historical scenarios spanning the lifetime of the tank, from an armoured car action in 1914 to the Middle East conflicts of recent history.

Name: Zoo-Spiel
Description:
Childrens' game of collecting animals in the form of cardboard tiles from a board representing a safari type environment.

Players roll dice and then move that many spaces exactly in an attempt to land on the correct space to collect the animal.

Person with the most animals at the end is named the Zoo Director & the winner.

(My German is not the best so if anyone cares to translate the rule manual and update this description please do.)

Name: Future War Commander: Fast Play Tabletop Wargame Rules for Combined-Arms Operations, The Future
Description:
FutureWarCommander is a wargame in line with Blitzkrieg Commander: Fast-Play Tabletop Wargame Rules for Combined-Arms Operations, 1936-45 and Cold War Commander: Fast-Play Tabletop Wargame Rules for Combined-Arms Operations, 1946+.

FutureWarCommander is an exciting wargame that allows you to re-create battles of the future using miniatures on a tabletop. Command anything from a company right up to a division and get a result in 2-3 hours without becoming bogged-down in detail. Suitable for any scale miniatures from 2mm right up to 28mm (including 6mm, 10mm, 15mm and 20mm) and no re-basing is required.

The rules come as a 140-page A4-sized perfect bound book with over 60 full colour pictures that illustrate how to play the game. These feature real miniatures as you see them on the gaming table. You also get a double-sided A4-sized quick reference sheet.

The game can be played at one of three levels: 1 base = 1 Platoon (the scale the game was designed for), 1 base = 1 Squad or Individual Vehicle, or 1 miniature = 1 Soldier or Vehicle. The ground scale is 1cm = 20m or 1cm = 10m respectively. One turn represents up to 30 minutes of real-life action.

Main Features
The main features of the game include:
-command system that emphasizes the fog of war in a simple but effective manner 
-the same mechanism for casualty resolution throughout 
-rules for infantry, armour, reconnaissance, artillery, aircraft and future technology 
-examples of play using colour pictures of miniatures "in-action" to illustrate the game 
-minimal set-up time - simply assemble your forces and play 
unique points system that allows for unequal forces but an equal chance of victory 
-41 well presented army lists covering the miniatures of 15 different manufacturers 
-11 scenarios for simulating combined-arms warfare of the future 
-suitable for solo, two-player & multi-player games at home, at the club, or in the garden! 
-one double-sided quick reference sheet included 
-no supplements - all you need to play in one book

Future War Commander Skirmish!
The book includes four pages of rules and three army lists to allow you to play at the skirmish level using individual figures. This means you can use the same core rules to play futuristic games in 6mm and 28mm with the minimum of fuss! Take a look at the Surgical Strike battle report to see how the game plays at this level.

Name: Red vs. Gray
Description:
Red vs. Gray is hex-and-counter wargame without a historical background. It is relatively light and plays in about an hour, although the time will depend not only on the speed of the players but their style of play.

Counter density is low at ten units per player. The rules are less than five pages and should be easily picked up by those familiar with hex-and-counter games.

The game has a few unique elements in the rules. Including conditional casualties in the combat resolution table, and a distinct endgame phase triggered when one side loses a certain amount of combat strength.

Name: Bomber Raid & Evade
Description:
The Game is all about A Lancaster Bomber Raid, and evading the German Fighters in a WW2 setting. you record damage and fuel, and may also parachute if hit.

You will recognize straight away how it feels like a boardgame, and will be playing it within 2-5 mins.

The game is in Electronic form for downloading via the net, it can be resized or split to fit on A4 sheets of paper as its simple in principal.
 The game is suitable for electronic play in Avalomhilly boardgame host and will probably easy be converted to Vassal and cyberboard.

Name: Letter Recognition Game
Description: Shaped bright-looking letters are matche to the corresponding self-correcting cut-outs.  Designed for solitaire play or in competition for up to four children to get the most matched letters.

Name: Animal Spelling Game
Description: Charming animal drawings are put together and then matched to special die cut letter cards fitting into self-correcting slots to spell out their names.  Designed for solitaire play or in competition for up to four children to get the most words.  #603 in the series

Name: Number Recognition Game
Description: Colorful number cards 1-10 with matching concept cards and heavy plastic markers for sel-correcting games to learn numbers and counting.  Designed for solitaire play or in competition for up to four children to get the most corectly matched numbers to concept.

Name: Number Fishing Game
Description: A set of colorful cut-out numbered fish with colorful matching cards.  The Children fish for the right numbers and stock up their fish ponds (the matching cards).  Essentially, it's like most fishing games except that you have toget the numbers on your pond card.  First one to get the numbers on his or her card wins.

Name: Find and Read Game
Description: Action words are matched to illustrations of the things children do every day, giving exciting motivation for speaking and word recognition activities.  OK, exciting is a bit of a stretch (just using Ed-U--Cards advert speak... :p).  Essentially 1-4 children race to get more matches than the others; the one with the most matches wins.

Name: Swing Swang
Description: There is a ball on a string that you have to get into cups on the board, worth different points.  The player holds one end of the string and swings the ball, then uses the string to attempt to get the ball to drop in the cup they want.  The winner is the person with the most points.

Name: Colonial Adventures!  Fortunes Won & Lost
Description:
From the website....

"Zanzibar!

Just saying the word makes you think of far off places and high adventure. Okay, maybe not so much if you’re a Poor Bloody Infantryman but for an Officer and a Gentleman the “Age of Imperialism” (1850 – 1914) was the best of times.
A time where young men could garner fame and fortune in dark and dangerous lands. A time where heroes could be made in a day. And a time where death could come swiftly and from unexpected places.

Colonial Adventures allows you to recreate these “dirty little wars” of European expansion on the tabletop. Refight the heroic stand at Rourke’s Drift or try and change the result at Isandhlwana. But it isn’t just about the British and Zulus. It’s also about the French Foreign Legion, Berber horsemen, Imperial German forces, Masai warriors, the Russian army, Pathan tribesmen, and much more.

Whether you’re an experienced Colonials player or a novice just starting the period, Colonial Adventures is right for you. Here’s just a few reasons why.


     In the book you’ll find over a dozen armies to choose from and another twenty online.



     We’ve included “open ended” scenarios to fight new and unique battles every time you use them.



     You can play solo, all on the same side against the game, or head to head.



     We provide online support to answer any questions you may have as they come up and usually in less than 24 hours.


So have a seat, grab a spot of tea, and get ready for hours of fun. Welcome to the world of ...

Colonial Adventures!"

These miniatures rules are available in print and PDF.

Name: Slacker
Description:
Slacker is a card-based game where players try to get through the work day doing as little work as possible!  Cards include Workload (which you try to force on other players), Excuses (to avoid doing the work),and Time Cards (which move the clock towards 5pm).

From the cover:  Play Slacker, the only game where you can tell your boss it's against your religion to answer the phones.  The game where you win by doing the least.  Slacker... Tell your boss the things you've only dreamed of.

Name: Firsts and Thirds
Description:
Players take control of one of six nations, which is either a First-World nation or a Third-World nation.  Every turn, nations collect income, produce resources, and then can trade resources with other nations in order to collect the proper money and resources to expand their infrastructure, or to apply towards solving national problems such as overpopulation, hostile neighbors, aging industry, etc.

The game was developed as an educational tool, and comes with a lesson plan.

Name: Rekushu
Description:
Rekushu (semi-transliteration of "Rectangle" into Japanese) is a territory game played on a square board.

Players take turns placing their stones on empty intersections trying to form the vertices of rectangular regions. A rectangle that doesn't have other stones or claimed territory in its interior can be claimed by a player. The object is to have the majority of claimed cells when the board fills up.

Name: Left & Right
Description:
The gameboard is a circle divided into four areas. Each player has one area where he tries to achieve certain combinations of stones while avoiding others. 
Each round you put two stones in your hand. Stones in your left hand will turn the gameboard (so you can "steal" areas from your opponent), stones on the right hand will be put on the board.

The title refers to the turning of the gameboard and the placing of the stones (dark stones always go on the left, light stones to the right side of the board)

Name: The Kingdom of Ierendi
Description:
The Game is a battle system in the Gazeteer N. 04 of D&D World, cover the naval battle (with Hex  and counters) in Mystara world.

The system is very simple and it born for recreate the possible war (tactics battle or entire campaigns) between the various kingdoms that make up the world of Mystara.

Name: Mighty Armies: Ancients
Description:
Mighty Armies: Ancients is a fast, easy to learn rule set that allows you to command a host of Ancient Armies. Featuring a modified version of the original Mighty Armies system, MA:A let’s you march against the Armies of your opponents to prove who is the greater General!

Mighty Armies: Ancients Features:
-    A Build Your Own Army System. You can build armies historically or design your own army to suit your campaign. You can even decide on the troop quality. Will you field veteran troops or will you recruit common soldiers for your War!
-    Use your Existing Armies. Already have a 15mm army based up for another system? No problem! You can use MA:A with any basing as long as your Opponent is based the same. There are no strict rules for basing in MA:A! 
-    Field Multiple Armies for Big Battles! Armies in MA:A are designed for 60 Pts. Convert the 60pt  Armies into Divisions and field 240 pts for Big Battles! 
-    Campaign System
-    Siege and Stronghold System
-    Army Build Examples

Rebel Minis is excited about the release of Mighty Armies: Ancients. It is designed for 15mm scale, but some of our play testers have even converted the system to 28mm. Each 60pt game takes between 30-60 minutes. We will be supporting the system with tournament and prizes and welcome any feedback or comments.

For more information, check out the Forum here: http://www.mightyarmiesonline.info
 or 
www.rebelminis.com

Name: Gugu Equilibrista
Description: This is a dexterity game from Brazil for 2-4 players.  It consists of a arced base with a flat caricature of boy; his hands clip on and hold a bar.  On your turn, you roll a die and you place however many disks that the die says onto the bar.  The die has an empty side, 2 ones, 2 two's, and one three.

Name: Space Race
Description:
Space Race - Wedloop om de maanmineralen - Course pour les minereaux de la luna - Race for the moon minerals

Space Race is a game where players compete to be the first to land on the moon with their rocket ship and return to earth with precious moon minerals. Players can choose and switch between several pre-printed color dotted orbit lines to reach the moon or earth.

The game contains a full color playing board, 30 plastic rockets in 6 colors and 3 dice (red, green, white)

'The game is published and printed in 1970 in the dutch language but was first sold in 2008' (quoting the salesman).

Home Page: http://www.spacerace-voorthuizen.nl/indexEN.html

Name: Hardball Wars
Description:
HardBall Wars is the “brother” to our football game, GridIron Wars. While I was designing GridIron Wars, an idea popped into my head
regarding a similar method to resolve a baseball game. After putting the idea to paper and mailing it to a couple of trusted friends,
HardBall Wars was born. HardBall Wars is simple enough for a child to learn, but robust enough to satisfy even the most veteran of baseball gamer.

Many may wonder, why a baseball game? Aren’t there plenty of good ones already on the market? In short, the answer is yes. There are many
fantastic baseball games on the market. With HardBall Wars, I’m really not re-inventing the wheel. You’ll never hear me tout the game as
better or more realistic than any other game currently on the market.

However, having said that, I do feel like this game stands up well against any other baseball game in terms of what is truly most important,
the “fun factor”. My testers and I have had an absolute blast playing the game. The unique batter-pitcher interface, combined with the X-
Factor deck, makes the game unique and in my humble opinion very fun to play.

My philosophy with Downey Games has always been to price games as low as possible, making the games accessible to all. Most current baseball
board games sell in the $50-$60 range. While that is reasonable to most, it does make it an expensive proposition to purchase multiple
seasons or teams. With HardBall Wars, I’ve purposely designed the game with a cost factor in mind. For that same $50 or $60 you’ll be able
to purchase multiple seasons of HardBall Wars. Also unlike other games, we strive to rate nearly every player who stepped foot on the field
of play.

HardBall Wars is based upon a modified log5 method. That may not mean much to some, but using this method allows the pitcher and batter to
"Interact" on every at-bat. Rather than a 50/50 model or a generic pitcher grade, with HardBall Wars you'll see the difference between
pitchers and batters and their impact on the at-bat in a very visual way. You'll also immediately see the difference in righty/lefty
matchups at the plate.

Fielding is not neglected in HardBall Wars. You'll see the difference between the gold glove shortstop and the lead gloved fielder not only
in terms of errors committed but also the ability to turn hits into outs.

The most unique aspect of HardBall Wars is our introduction of the X-Factor Deck. And often times it can generate a lot of excitement.

Within the X-Factor deck just about anything you’ve ever seen in a baseball game can take place. From run downs, appeals, dropped third
strikes, rain delays, rain outs, ejections, brawls to even the extremely bizarre like the now famous Pine Tar incident—all are possible
within the X-Factor Deck.

The deck is far more than just a Rare Play mechanism. There are many conditional events within the deck and even some very mundane plays.

The X-Factor deck simulates the events that happen in real life that as a tabletop gamer you don’t often see in your own gaming. One can see
something out of the ordinary in almost every baseball game in real life. And we have brought that to the tabletop through the use of the X
-Factor Deck.

With HardBall Wars, the decisions as a manager are all yours. You decide when to steal bases. You decide when to Hit and Run or Sacrifice
the runner to the next base. You'll make the call when to intentionally walk the opposition’s slugger, or when to bring the infield in to
cut down a runner at the plate. You'll make the call as when to attempt a squeeze bunt or play for the big inning. You'll make the call to
bring in the lefty specialist to face the opposing left hand slugger, or stick with your right hand throwing starter. With HardBall Wars, you
may even be ejected from the game! Nearly every situation that faces a major league skipper is replicated in the game.

The printed game features game charts printed in full-color, the season of your choice, 3 dice, a die-cut X-Factor deck also printed in full color, score sheets all packaged in a sturdy game box.

Name: Battle B-Dabeast
Description: Test your B-Daman battle skills with this target game that's loaded with new gameplay and challenges. Just load the Iba Blaster and blast armor off the B-Dabeast with all the power you've got! Target challenge B-Dabeast figure comes with Iba Blaster and 3 B-Daballs for sharpening your skills prior to battle.

Name: Dalek Battle through Time Game
Description:
From the box:

"The TARDIS is running low on Artron energy and the Doctor needs your help.  Step aboard and travel through time and space trying to be the first player to reach the water tower refuelling station in the centre of Cardiff.

Sounds easy ... but not when the evil Dalek Caan is roaming the universe trying to EXTERMINATE you!!

In this fast paced action game, with moving Dalek model with rotating turret and sound FX!, race your TARDIS around the board being pursued by Dalek Caan.  As you journey through the past, present and future, Dalek Caan is relentless and never far away.  Ho could emerge from one of the 3D time portal tunnels and be on your trail at any time!!"

The game is a simple roll and move game, with a few options on paths you can take to reach the end.  The twist is that there is a second track with a battery-powered Dalek that travels around the board and if you're in its path then your sent into a black hole and miss your turn.  There are two plastic "railway points" that ensure that the Dalek takes different paths.

Name: Haunted Destinies
Description:
Haunted Destinies is an identity mystery game set on the Scottish moors.  At the start of the game, one player is secretly assigned the role of Opener, but no one - not event the player who is the Opener - knows who the Opener is.  The Opener card, and other attribute cards, are distributed to the players in destiny piles.

As the game progresses, your destiny, and the destiny of the other players, will gradually be revealed. The Opener is destined to break the walls that keep past, present future, the dead, and the living separate. If you discover that you are The Opener, your goal is to complete the opening ritual by killing all of the other players. If you are not The Opener, your goal is to bind him or her and stop the opening ritual.

If you die and the game is not over, you become a ghost. Ghosts can only win if a Haunting card that gives them a win condition is in play. What are Haunting cards and how do they work? You add Haunting cards to your destiny pile when you are haunted by ghosts or if you fail a destiny search. A Haunting card comes into play when another player probes your destiny pile and finds a Haunting card.

Haunted Destinies uses a tiled board system similar to Betrayal at the House on the Hill, but each tile edge indicates the minimum number of movement points need to leave through that edge.  Some tiles have an "X", indicating that you can not leave that way.  This tile setup creates interesting, semi-solid maze-like boards that are different each game.

Haunted Destinies is a game for three to six players. It uses a custom set of board tiles, three custom card decks, a black six sided die, and a white six sided die. You can download the custom parts and the rules at http://www.invisible-city.com/play/499/haunted-destinies. A four-player game takes about 60 minutes to play. Since it deals with ritual sacrifice and murder, Haunted Destinies is appropriate for ages 16 and up.

Name: Babbela
Description:
Players taking turns putting stones on the lines of the game board. Once every stone is placed, they move their stones to the intersections. If a stone doesnt have any intersection to move through, he van be put on the area between the lines.
Once all moves are done you get negative points for stones remaining on the lines. Fewer begative points wins.

Name: Wantu
Description: Players are taking turns, switching the two stones on the board, recieving an additional stone in the process. The possibilitys of switching are very constrained and they get fewer during play. Whoever makes the last possible move loses.

Name: Voodoo Party
Description:
Players have to build a word chain, i.e. the next word has to start with the same letter that the previous word ended with. Exceptions: If the previous word ended with L or N, the player has to name certain "magical words".
If someone makes a mistake, they get a needle in their Voodoo doll and have to do some silly thing until the end of the game.
If a player makes too many mistakes, they are out.

Name: Elixir of Life
Description:
From the Publisher:

Can you be the first to move up through the levels of transformation and release the Elixir of Life?
Will you be a true alchemist on your journey or will you bluff your way through? Will you be able to stop the false alchemists?

In this game you can test not only your tactical skills but your ability to bluff and double bluff by playing your cards right

Name: Impossum
Description:
[Text by the publisher:] 3 card games about very strange names of animals, such as "blood-striped blenny", "bobolink", "spectacled warbler" and "brown egg frog" (these are eqivalents of the names in English - by now the game ist available only with German names).
You try to get rid of your cards. Each card shows six incredible names of animals, each of them belonging to one of these species: mammals, reptiles, fish, birds, butterflies, and impossums. Only the first five species are "regular" species. The impossums are fake animals (impossible animals). Their sole purpose is to provide suggestions for bluffing. Bluffing is important for winning - and for having fun!
One game is about guessing to what species an animal belongs. As the animal names must be read aloud, it is good exercice for kids to read and pronounce.
The other two games are different in depth and demand. There are alphabetical and morphemic rules for putting down cards. For example: 
You can put down a card only if 
- either it shows the name of an animal of the particular category that fits alphabetically (= starting with the same letter as the reference animal or with its first letter following or coming before that letter), or if
- a part of the name of an animal is identical with a part of the name of the reference animal (example: "blue-and-gold-fusilier", a fish, thus matches with "blue-crowned motmot", a bird). If it belongs to the same species, you can put down a further card, if it belongs to another category you just switch the species.
If both is not possible, you can try some bluffing. The cards are played face down.
You must pronounce the name of the animal when putting your card down. Each card put down can be controlled. When your bluffing is detected, you get malus points. When you habe put your cards down "regularly", however, the one who has controlled gets malus points. Chances are good not to be detected when bluffing: all animal names (more than 1250) are very strange indeed, so its not obvious, when you invent a name on your own or use an impossum. Unless you blush... [end of publisher's text]

Name: Catch me if you can
Description:
This is an abstract game a little similar to checkers.
Theme is rabbits and hunters, but that is of no meaning in the game - rabbits can kill hunters as well as the other way around.

Each player has a set of blocks numbered from 1 through 7, which is hidden from his opponent. 
The number represents the amount of spaces the piece can move.
The board consists of a grid of 9*7 squares.

Goal of the game is to capture opposing pieces. In order to do this, you have to enclose an opponent's block in a straight line between two of your own blocks. These blocks have to sport consecutive numbers, e.g. 2-3 order 4-5.

The game is over, if one of the players has no such pairs left. The player who can no longer make captures loses.

Name: Escape from the Haunted Mansion
Description:
From the Disney Experience website:

"Can you escape from the Haunted Mansion before the clock strikes '13'? Begin your journey in the mansion's attic, winding your way through haunted corridors and the ghost-filled cemetery. But, watch out! Madame Leota is performing many spells and enchantments that may or may not work in your favor."

Download, print, cut, and assemble on your own.

SPECIAL NOTE:
Be advised that this game does NOT fold up or disassemble for easy storage! It's big, and it takes up a good portion of space.

Name: Jamaica: Extra Treasures
Description:
Free expansion for Jamaica including three new treasures to be found. The new treasures include:

Rum: +1 token of the same type when loading
Sextant: Gives the player the option to move one additional space
Anchor: Gives the player the option to move one less space

Name: Legends of the Ancient World: Fire in the Streets
Description:
Fire in the Streets is a programmed adventure using Dark City Games Legends of the Ancient World rule set. These rules provide gameplay very similar to that of Melee and Wizard from Metagaming. This adventure is compatible with those games as well.

Battles are fought with counters on a hex map that is included with the game.

From the Publisher: "As fires spring up around the streets of Redpoint, the leader of a group of anti-slavery rebels is captured. While the eyes of authority are on the chaos, you must find this hero of the people, searching through winding alleys, open markets and temples for elusive clues. As you go, you discover others are using the distractions for their own ends..."

This module is a campaign guide and urban adventure for the Stormspeake Penninsula
Families: Series: Legends of the Ancient World (Dark City Games)

Name: Star Wars Adventures
Description:
Star Wars Adventures is a series of novel-driven set-piece adventure games marketed for direct to home sales by Scholastic, Inc. and Lucas Books / Lucasfilms LTD. The game is generally structured along the lines of the 1970s-1980s era "choose your own adventure" (CYOA) novels, except using pregenerated heroic characters from the Star Wars universe, more linear story lines and an "adventure points" scoring system. Players risk losing points for making poor decisions and for bad die rolls, but unlike most earlier CYOA books, seldom (if ever) risk character death. While the adventures are designed for solo play, the adventure points system allows for competitive, partnership or cooperative play by several players.

Characters have different RPG-like attributes (name, life-form, allegiance, charm, knowledge, navigation, power, skill, stealth, strength, weaponry and talents). Devices and Powers that the characters might use are rated for accuracy in different circumstances. Similarly, Vehicles are rated by type, speed, distance, stealth and weaponry. Combinations of these attributes are used along with d10 or d20 rolls to determine "adventure numbers" during decisions and confrontations that, in turn, affect both the direction of the storyline and the adventure points score.

Star Wars Adventures is packaged in a plastic carrying case shaped like a flattened Clone Trooper helmet. The base game includes a membership card, adventure poster, d10, d20, character cards, power cards, device cards, vehicle cards, an adventure guide, notebook, point pad, adventure novel and game book. Expansions include additional cards of all types, posters, novels, magazines and game books. Modules in the series are as follows:

1. Hunt the Sun Runner (Ryder Windham, 2002) -- This module is set in the period between Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace and Star Wars Episode II: Attack of the Clones. A ghost ship is on a crash course with a helpless planet. First you must find it. Then you must stop it.

Name: SUDOKU: Ergänzungs-Set
Description: This is an expansion for SUDOKU - Das Brettspiel. The box contains 100 new gameboards.

Name: All-purpose Miniatures Rules
Description:
A booklet (120 pages) containing three universal sets of miniature rules and some supplemental materials.  Main rules are:

Section 1: Skirmish Combat (For 25mm figures. 24 or less figures per side. For 15mm figures, halve all distances)
1 inch = 10 feet, 1 figure = 1 man.

Section 2: Mass Combat (For 25mm figures. About 24-150 figures per side. For 15mm figures, halve all distances)
1 inch = 10 feet, 1 stand = 3 men, 1 unit = 2-4 stands (6-12 men)

Section 3: Massive Combat (For 1/300 (6mm) figures. More than 150 figures)
1 inch = 20 feet, 1 stand = 6 men or 1 vehicle

Supplemental materials are:
Section 4: Vehicles (land, air, naval and space vehicles can be designed)
Section 5: Giant Robots
Section 6: Creature Creation
Section 7: Magic and Psionic Powers
Section 8: Building Your Army
Section 9: Designer's Notes
Section 10: Army Lists (sample armies and scenarios)

(worksheets and templates)

NOTE: These rules require use of at least one d12 (twelve-sided die).

[From Back of Cover]
In one place! All the rules you'll ever need to game with any miniatures you own! Any time period! Any genre! And any combination! The game system has been designed with ease of play in mind, emphasizing fun over rules, excitement over monotony.[...]

ISBN=1-929332-10-6
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: World cup cricket
Description:
In this all luck cricket game the pitch is represented by a  6 by 6 grid on which the fielder places his nine men. The bowler uses a spinner to determine the outcome of the bowl. If it's a hit further spins determine which square the ball lands in. Should there be a fielder in that square the batsman is out, otherwise the lower of the two numbers on the spinner is the number of runs scored. After each over the fielder can reposition his men.
Play continues until all eleven batsmen have been dismissed. Then the other team (player) have an innings. The winner is the player who scores most runs.

Name: Muumien sanasirkus
Description:
Muumien sanasirkus is a box with two seperate games. Both games are use letter tiles and the aim is to create words with the tiles. The theme of the game is based on the Muumi characters.

Game is a Finnish Game of the Year 2008 finalist.

Name: Action Zulu
Description: Game similar to Action D-Day, with a chessboard that simulates the battleground where (with 4 mountains to be positioned to liking) you are moved the miniatures through the game of the card and draughts of die.

Name: Zooloretto: The Savings Book
Description:
The Savings Book is part of the Zooloretto-News No. 1.
With this little addtition a player can get additional money during the game.

It is also part of the Rio Grande Games Exp. Pack #2 with several mini expansions.

Expands: 
Zooloretto

Also available as part of the Zooloretto: Goodie-Box.

Home Page & Newsletter:

     www.zooloretto.com 


(German, english, dutch, hungarian, spanish, swedish)

Name: Mystic Master
Description:
"Mystic Master -- an adventure for the mind"

Presented as a game, Mystic Master is pretty unusual for its time. Coming in on the fringe of the D&D explosion in the early 1980s. It's games like this that made some people take the magic use in D&D way too seriously.

From the tube:

"Mystic Master is a unique and enjoyable adventure designed by a research psychologist to test, challenge and help develop the fantastic powers of the mind. Join forces with Merlin in mastering mystical mental powers of ESP. It's fun and easy to play. The game comes complete with:

"A long-lasting, attractive, vinyl game board, 18 specially designed mystic image cards and easy-to-follow multiple game instructions."

No designer is actually credited in the rules or anywhere else. It also comes with two gold plastic tokens.

Movement is literally governed by guessing (erm, divining) what card(s) is being held up, is closest to the top of the deck, etc.

Name: A Castle for All Seasons: Winter Cards
Description:
This expansion to A Castle for All Seasons was released at the fair SPIEL in October, 2008.  The expansion contains 6 new winter cards which are shuffled with the existing winter cards. As only 6 cards are needed for playing the game the cards may replace the cards of the original game.

The cards were given as exclusives to everyone who bought the game A Castle for All Seasons directly at the booth of Eggert-Spiele (German edition) or The Game Master (Dutch edition).

The cards are:

     Hungersnot (Famine)
     Sonderzoll (Extra Duty)
     Raubritter (Robber Baron)
     Feuerstelle (Fireplace)
     Strassenbau (Road Works)
     Bettler (Beggar)

Name: Trapdoor Checkers
Description: A twist on classic checkers. On each turn players spin to see if they either move, or open and close trap doors. If your checker is on one of the trap doors – look out it might fall through. Adds cunning and luck so that kids and parents have equal chances of winning.

Name: Walt Disney's ACTION GAME Pirates of the Caribbean
Description:
Pirate Ship shooting game based on Disney's "Pirates of the Caribbean" ride.

Game includes two pirate ships with cardboard sails and hull and two plastic cannons for each.  You load and shoot black plastic cannonballs trying to knock down the three plastic pirate figures on each others ship.  When the third pirate figure is knocked down, a trigger releases the "Pirates Treasure" and you win the game.

Also included are 5 Buoy Markers and 6 Course Cards for determining movement of your ship before shooting.

Name: Quintorium
Description: Players use their color of cards to make five in a row. Each player starts out with either the red or black half of the deck and attempt to make five in a row either vertically, horizontally or diagonally with their color. A card may be played on top of an opposing card with the same rank.

Name: Speculation
Description:
Speculation is played using two standard decks of cards divided into a stack for each suit, with six cards removed from each stack. Each suit represents a commodity.

Each round one card from each stack is turned over to give the price for that commodity. All players may buy or sell the four commodities. If a face card is revealed for a commodity all holdings in it are wiped out. The wealthiest player after a set number of rounds wins the game.

Name: Capitalist Canasta
Description:
Capitalist Canasta is played with two standard decks of cards and a supply of money. Players attempt to make small melds and cash them in to get enough money to make larger melds which are worth more money.

On a turn a player draws a card and then may make melds, but they have to be paid for: 5-10 cost face value but J-A cost significantly more. Deuces are wild. Cards may be added to existing melds by paying for them.

Melds may be sold to the bank. Melds may also be raided with 3s and raids may defended against with 4s.

Name: Tortoise & Hare
Description:
Tortoise & Hare is a racing game that uses two decks of standard cards. The goal is to reach 100 points.

On a turn a player turns over one card and then may turn over more, but if a face card is drawn they bust.

When a player reaches 100 points they may stop or continue. When a player does stop the other players have one more turn to try to beat them.

The winner gets antes and penalties from a pot, but the rules do not state to what end; presumably one plays a number of rounds and then the player with the most chips from these pots wins the overall game.

Name: Missouri Rummy
Description: Missouri Rummy is a rummy/poker variation where poker hands are used to win various pools of chips. For instance, a pool will made for club flush, diamond flush, heart flush, full house, etc. and it is up to the players to determine when to play their hand for that pool and cash-out. The longer the pool remains, the more chips it can potentially pay out.

Name: Fund Manager
Description:
Released in Essen 2008, Fund Manager is a game about the stock market. Player with the most asset, cash and portfolio, in the end wins. The game comes with two decks of cards, one sheet for stock prices, paper money and a board.

Fund Manager can be played with either three or four players. Depending on the number of players each have either three or four action chits numbered from one to three. Players use this chits to move one single pawn around the game board. When the pawn lands in a space that action is then executed. These actions spaces include buying/ selling stocks, drawing random events from the deck of cards, rolling dice to see which companies rise or fall and collecting cash at the completion of one round. When round is completed the chits are turned over and are ready to be used again. Game is played for eight round and takes about one hour to complete.

Name: Ranabag
Description:
Players advance their frog by taking frogs from the bag and placing them on the board. But some frogs don't like others - so frogs also have to be at the right color. By placing frog of the wrong color You find Yourself right where You started. But You can always stop risking and say that You'll stay right where You got with the last frog.

At Essen '08 there also was this poster: "These frogs are not edible!"

Name: Manimals: Ozeane, Küsten & Pole 1
Description:
(from the rules) There are millions of different animal species world-wide, which have not even yet been studied. Likewise there are many animals living in the oceans, at the coast and pols which most people have already seen, but sometimes cannot put a name to or say much about.

GOAL OF THE GAME

Simultaneously, all of the players try to collect as many animals as possible with a certain characteristic. Whoever collects the most animals wins.

Name: Spuk im Schloss
Description:
This game should be played in darkness. Every player gets a certain number of fluorescent cards into his hand and has to pass one of these to his left every round. Whenever one player collects a set of four equal pictures he calls the end of the round.

Points are scored for ending the round and for ghosts which can be either positive or negative, depending on the ghosts' face which can not be recognized in darkness.

Name: Lariat
Description:
Lariat is played on the surface of a cylinder with one open end and one closed end.  As the name suggests, players must form a "lariat", a group of stones which either includes the center cell or surrounds the center cell, and which includes a cell on the lip of the cylinder.

Lariat rule sheet:
  http://www.marksteeregames.com/Lariat_rules.pdf

Name: The Cell Game
Description:
From the publisher: The object of the game is to assemble a "complete" plant or animal cell.

This is an educational and fun game simulating the workings of a cell.  Each player can complete two actions per turn, which consist of cellular functions like respiration as well as drawing "cell event" cards that simulate important environmental changes.  Each player must accumulate as many points as possible, the play is complete when a player has assembled the parts of a complete cell.  The player with the most points wins.

Name: IGOR Brainwash Game
Description:
From the back of the packaging:
Brainwash is an exciting memory game featuring characters from the hit movie Igor, and the Dreaded Brainwashed game play card!

IGOR Brainwash Game includes a total of 51 cards: 2 brainwashed cards, 1 Old Bone card and 24 pairs of cards that show characters from the movie.

3 sets of rules are included with the game. All are based on the classic Memory game but two of them offer simple twists.

Game titles are:  
Classic Memory, Brainwash Memory Game and Old Bone.

Name: Queen of Hearts
Description: Queen of Hearts is an Alice in Wonderland themed Hearts variant.  It is played with a 36 card, non-standard deck (spades, diamonds, and clubs suits contain cards A-9, hearts consists of A-8,Q).  The 36 card deck allows the full deck to be used when playing with 2, 3, or 4 players.

Name: Viamala
Description: A simple game where people try to build a path by laying tiles on the table. These tiles can be acquired by rolling a die. You can also use the die result to obtain action cards or move the pawn.

Name: Apokalypse
Description:
In Apokalypse each player gets a hidden card that gives him his game goal. There are two different cards, good and evil. The Good players can win all together, but only one Evil player can win.

On your turn you can play a population card, if you put it on the Good side you must give one of the cards from your hand to another player. If you put it on the Evil side you can steal a card from another player. You can also play cards to protect your population from the Apokalypse riders.

The game ends after the 4th Apokalypse rider.

The Good players win when all player's populations are more Good than Evil, and the Good players have scored more points than the evil players. The Evil player wins when the populations are more Evil than Good, and the Evil players have more points than the Good players, but only the evil player with the most points win.

Name: ZORBOW: A Galactic Adventure With Numbers
Description:
ZORBOW was designed to teach and reinforce the math skills in addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

Players place number and problem cards in the correct patterns as they attempt to solve math problems.

Can be used in the classroom as a team game.

Contains 1080 cards, plastic card holders, and rules.

Includes a Sign Language version.

(c)1989 Abby Educational Products, Atlanta GA

Name: Madagascar Escape 2 Africa Game
Description:
Educational matching and race game based on the characters from the movie Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa

From the box:
"No Animal Left Behind!
Take off on a journey of fun with the cast of Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa.  Players move their characters across the game board on a trip to Africa.  Any time they match a card with the space they are on, they choose a Colorforms "Stick-On".  The story board fills up as the matches are made.  The more matches the better the final story.  The player to reach Africa with the most matches wins, but everyone wins by creating a unique story every time!

The game teaches and enhances memorization, matching, and comparison skills.  It also encourages young childrens' imaginations as they build stories around their favorite characters.

Contents:
Game board
15 picture cards
4 character game pieces
Spinner
Story Board
Sheet of 15 Colorforms Stick-ons
Instructions

Name: Gold Rush in a Tin
Description:
This is a dice and chips game, where players roll two dice and attempt to place a majority of their chips in one of 12 spaces in four different colors for an area majority win.

Components are two six side dice, gameboard, chips, instructions, and game tin.

Name: Naturquartett Wasser
Description:
Naturquartett Wasser is a small collection of games by Haba. The cards are Wind- & Wetter-Karten; sturdy cards that you can clean when taken outside.

Components:

36 Cards
1 Wooden frog
12 Wassersteine (beads)
Rules

With this small package of components, you can play different games: Quartett (A Game of Authors), a Quartett variant, a Quartett variant for 2 players, a Charades / pantomime game. The rules also suggest to go outside with the cards and search for all the animals pictured on the cards. The number on the card shows how many points you earn for finding that animal. The more rare the animal, the more points you get.

Also in the rules: a few tips on other outdoor activities. Measure the depth and speed of water, make your own watermill, etc.

Name: Eurasia
Description:
This two to six player game of the rise and decline of historical empires could be described as a cross between History of the World and Vinci with a little Britannia thrown in.  While the participants play historical empires, the game does not recreate any particular history, hence allowing players to fully exercise strategic judgment.

Players control empires on a map of Eurasia, ranging from the earliest history to the Mongols.  As time passes empires decline and finally disappear and new ones appear, but in the meantime receive new armies depending on terrain type and empire type (steppe, desert, agricultural).  Empires have historical point centers, and also have historically-based special characteristics such as leaders, religious zeal, light cavalry, and cataphracts.

There are 80 empires, with optional rules for use of 30 event cards.

Depending on the number of players, their familiarity with the game, and the victory target selected, the game lasts 60-140 minutes.

Name: Telendar
Description:
A bounch of adventurers explore the cursed kingdom of Telendar, in search of a key to close the Gates of Evil, end the curse and win! They fight monsters with brute force and magic, gaining treasures and artifacts, they gain followers, visit strange places and they trade with each other or in the four burghs of the map.
But there is a ticking clock: the King of the realm is slowly dying. Each turn, an event card is turned over. This could lead to the King lose lives, and when the King dies all the players lose.
Each game is different, with a random 7x7 tiles map, tons of monsters and encounter in different combinations, and you need to use very different strategies every time like improving fighting skills, becoming a very powerful magician, exploring the land for money, tempting fate and, last but not least, trading watermelons.

Can be played solitaire.

Name: Großwildjagd in Afrika
Description: A game about hunting animals in Africa. Players roll dice and move their meeples. On many spots on the gameboard they can take a chance and shoot at elephants, lions, ...  For each "killed" animal they get counters worth from 1 point for a jackal up to 80 points for an elephant. Animals, which give many points are harder to kill than animals which give less points. All in all there are 29 different animals. During some actions the hunters also can die. When the surviving hunters are back in the native village, the one with the most points wins.

Name: The Grain Elevator
Description: The Grain Elevator is a campaign game for Advanced Squad Leader that appeared in the Critical Hit 1997 Special. It includes a two-page map of the famous grain elevator in Stalingrad, which was the scene of fierce fighting in September 1942.  The campaign game uses Critical Hit's Platoon Leader system for linking several days of combat (in this case four CG scenarios) into one game.

Name: Monopoly: Perry Rhodan
Description:
Monopoly - Perry Rhodan was a freebie given away at Essen 08.

It consists of a map printed on glossy paper and cards to be punched out. The rules appear to be standard Monopoly rules, but themed on the SF series Perry Rhodan, with sets of planets rather than hotels. Free Parking and Jail still make an appearance!

The game is printed in German but could easily be played by anyone familiar with ordinary Monopoly.

Name: Wort-Wexel
Description: Simple word game. Comes with 165 Plastic pieces with letters on.Aim of the game is to build and change the major word in the middle. If there is eg.the word STORE and you would have an Y you could change it to STORY and the E would be a point for you.

Name: Luckie Strike
Description: Players pass one card at a time to the player on their left, until one player completes a set of 4 matching. When the set is played on the table, all players grab for stick from the table. one player will not get a stick. The first player gets the letter of LUCKIE, the player without a stick gets the next letter of STRIKE. When the someone completes LUCKIE, you score +1 for each letter of LUCKIE, -1 for each letter of STRIKE, highest score wins.

Name: The Cat in the Sack
Description:
The Cat in the Sack is a very simple dexterity game. It consists of a large plastic base in the shape of a blue sack. Inside the sack is a large white cover for the sack on which is mounted a large plastic cat head. The cover is mounted to the sack with a large spring (reminiscent of a jack-in-the-box). Along the edge of the "sack" are 25 clips that hold the cover in place.

To play the game, you push the spring loaded cover down into place, securing it in place with the clips. The game begins and each player takes a turn removing one of the clips, trying not to let the cat out of the sack. The player who removes a clip and causes the cat to spring out of the sack, loses the game.

Name: Mehr oder Weniger
Description:
Counting quickly and snatching the correct number of cards from the middle of the table - that's almost all there is to it, but this is easier said than done. Since while checking the motifs and colours, there could suddenly be more or less.

The game contains 14 number cards that are laid out on the table. Each number card has three numbers on it. For each round, four motif or search cards are turned up. Players look at the search cards, which may show colours or symbols, then count the number of matching colours and symbols on the motif cards. When they think they've got the number right, they take one number card from the middle of the table.

The numbers are checked, and everyone who has a correct number cards scores a point. The number cards go back into the middle of the table and the next round begins.

If the cards turned up are only search cards, then the result is zero - and there are number cards with zero on them, so those are the ones people try to grab. If only motif cards are turned up, another set of cards is turned up.

There is a variation for 2 to 4 children aged 6 and up, with fewer number cards, placed the other way up so that there is only one number showing. In this version, the search cards and motif cards are separated and only one search card is turned up each round.

Name: Mel Allen's Baseball Game
Description: This game uses an 33â…“ LP recorded by New York Yankees announcer Mel Allen to determine the outcomes of baseball plays. Each side of the LP has seven tracks, for use in different game situations. Each track has four interleaved grooves announcing the resulting play, leading to different outcomes based on which groove happens to catch the phonograph needle.  The back of the LP sleeve itself is used as a game board.

Name: WWF Superstars Card Game
Description:
WWF Superstars Card Game was sold in double packs featuring two WWF wrestlers.  Each wrestler is represented by a 30-card deck, although the card distribution is identical for each deck.

Players draw a hand of four cards and take turns either playing or discarding a card and then drawing a new one.  Players try to have the highest Takedown card in the center stack.  Break] cards restart the stack.  If a player is unable to play a card, they must discard.  If your opponent discards, you can then play a Pin card, which can only be defeated by an Illegal Hold.  If you are able to play two [i]Pin[/i] cards and then a Referee, you gain 3 points, and a new round begins.  Else, if both players' decks run out, the last player to play a card gains 1 point.  The first player to 5 points wins.

Out of the box, the game is for 2 players.  However, a second set allows for 4-player tag team matches.

Name: Fair Shake
Description:
Fair Shake -- "The fun filled fast moving game of luck for two to six players"

(c)1972 Leisure Life

"The pace is quick, the action exciting in this fascinating game of dice and cards. Fair shake deals you a handful of fun."

Players are dealt five cards from a special deck and then roll five dice in an attempt to match the die roll with cards they hold. Players can make a second roll without revealing their card combinations.

Players score based on how quickly they discard matching sets.

Includes cards, dice, six plastic card holders, and rules printed on an illustrated storage insert.

Name: Trail of 98
Description:
Trail 98: A Historical Card Game of the Klondike Gold Rush.

Half-a-dozen cards make up the playing board,  and players use their cards (claims, goods, strike, hit, bonus, passage, provisions) to make their way from Seattle to Dawson and to lay down as many claims as possible. Player with the most claims wins. But you can put a hit card like Avalanche, to slow players down and it's likely you're run into a storm, sandbar, log jam or some other hit cards along the way.

From the instruction book: "Welcome to the Klondike gold Rush of 1898! This card game takes players up the scenic Inside Passage from Seattle through historic Skagway and along the rugged Chilkoot Trail to Dawson, where they work the gold fields. along the way, players encounter difficulties of the trail, as well as some bonuses..."

Name: LOOKEE
Description: Lookee is the "Search-A-Word Game", for 2 or more players, that can be played by those of all ages. The game consists of a plastic tile board and 100 various tiles each with a letter and point assigned to it on each side. The game has five different variations of play. In Game One: The grid begins empty except for the word LOOKEE spelled out in the center. Using at least one letter on the board each player must take turns making their own word (with the 7 tiles they began with) using at least one pre-existing tile.Each turn must be finished within 30 seconds. These words could be spelled forward, backward, horizontally, vertically or diagonally. Each player scores points for all the letters on their new word. After each turn, the player who went replenishes back to seven tiles. The player with the most points after the grid is filled is the winner. Game Two: First player to reach 100 points wins. In this game, the entire tile board is filled with letters at random. The first player tries to locate a word in any direction, and receives the added points for that word. The tiles used are then flipped over creating a new board every turn. The next player goes and so on. Only 30 seconds per turn. Game Three: Same as game two except additional option. Look for letter groupings that can be rearranged to form words. E.G. T,C,R,U,K can be TRUCK. First to 100 points wins. Game Four: Play solitaire by setting up the board as in Game One. Score as many points as possible in a given time period. Game Five: By using another game board, a duplicates version could be played by using identical letters and setting a time limit.

Name: Reed's Game of Base Ball
Description: Reed's Game of Base Ball is a dexterity game where players use little wooden bats to whack a dowel seated in a groove on the edge of the game board. The space where the dowel comes to rest indicates which Baseball play has occurred.

Name: Fourthought
Description: From the box. A Family Get Together Game.  A competitive fast moving game of skill & Strategy with a unique playing board.  There are three ways to line up your marbles and hundreds of ways to play and win.  Strategically designed blocking panels.  Mislead your opponent ... attack and counter attack.  Think one or two moves ahead and hope your opponent spoil your game plan.

Name: Klapse
Description:
Klapse - German for "Nuthouse" - is a Monopoly-like roll-and-move game with a strong satirical approach. There are two "circles" - the "locked ward" and the "open ward" - for the pawns to walk around and step on "event"-spaces of different kinds: New diagnosis, several events ...

The players try to get their pawns from the "locked" into the "open" ward and from there to freedom stepping on a "discharge" space. In the beginning, players draw a "diagnosis", which reduces their possibilities in walking forward.

There are many satirical cards and texts on the board, plus in the "active" variant (the full game) players can discard their "diagnosis" cards, when acting out the symptoms ...

A game without depth or strategic approach, but a pure mock and fun game about psychiatrists and looney bins - mainly made for people working in that area (the publisher is specialized in critical literature about psychiatry).

Name: Jerusalem
Description: Jerusalem is  a German Game about a sight-seeing tour in modern Jerusalem. The Players have the tasks to make photos of places of interest. The plans for each tour are hidden from the other players. Special events are handled by event-cards. Additionally the players have to bargain for special souvenirs. The player who was able to make all photos and buy all souvenirs first wins.

Name: Wedlock
Description: A game of skill, intrigue and fun(chess/draughts level). Based on 3,000 years of folklore, customs and superstitions of the spring festival of fertility. Players pit their wits against each other to move their own 15 pieces, which can be moved in varying ways, across the maroon and white board while outmaneuvering, blocking and capturing the pieces of their opponents with the aim of scoring the most points.
